div.p: This paper studies the problem of adaptively adjusted event-triggering mechanism-based fault detection for a class of discrete-time networked control system (NCS) with applications to aircraft dynamics. By taking into account the fault occurrence detection progress and the fault occurrence probability, and introducing an adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter, a novel event-triggering mechanism is proposed to achieve the efficient utilization of the communication network bandwidth. Both the sensor-to-control station and the control station-to-actuator network-induced delays are taken into account. The event-triggered sensor and the event-triggered control station are utilized simultaneously to establish new networkbased closed-loop models for the NCS subject to faults. Based on the established models, the event-triggered simultaneous design of fault detection filter (FDF) and controller is presented. A new algorithm for handling the adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter is proposed. Performance analysis verifies the effectiveness of the adaptively adjusted event-triggering mechanism, and the simultaneous design of FDF and controller.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: N ETWORKED control systems (NCSs) are control sys- tems wherein the control loops are closed through a shared band-limited digital communication network. The defining feature of NCSs is that control and feedback signals are transmitted among the systems' components in the form of data packets through a communication network. NCSs have been the subject of intensive research in areas from robust H 2 /H ∞ control [1], sequence-based control [2], fuzzy control [3], [4], quantized control [5], asynchronous sampling [6], time-varying sampling [7], [8], multirate control [9], [10], to observer-based control [11], and many more.

Industrial control systems are generally subject to faults. The work in [12] investigated fault-tolerant flight control design for aircraft systems. Fault detection has been an active research topic, and great efforts have been made to investigate fault detection and fault compensation for traditional control systems (see [13], [14] and the references therein). Some nice results on fault detection for NCSs have also been achieved [15]- [22]. Note that network-induced delays are ignored in [15]- [18]; plant state delays instead of networkinduced delays are taken into account in [19]; network-induced delays are not included in the established model in [20]; and the sensor-to-fault detection filter network-induced delays are considered in [21] and [22]. Moreover, no control input is considered in [21], while network-induced transmission delays of control inputs are ignored in [22]. In this paper, we introduce a control station consisting of the fault detection filter (FDF) and the controller to study the problem of fault detection. However, inserting the sensor-to-control station and the control station-to-actuator communication networks will induce network transmission delays inevitably. For NCSs subject to faults, since both the plant and the FDF are described as dynamic systems, taking into account the sensor-to-control station and the control station-to-actuator network-induced delays will introduce considerable difficulty for network-based modeling and the simultaneous design of FDF and controller. How to address these issues is practically valuable and still unresolved in [13]- [22]. This gives the first motivation of this paper.

In the aforementioned works, the plant states or measurement outputs are sampled at specific sampling periods and then transmitted to the controller and/or FDF periodically through a communication network. Generally speaking, transmitting all the sampled data packets can lead to a good system performance. However, this may not always be the truth. On the one hand, if the communication network cannot provide enough network bandwidth, releasing all the sampled data packets into the communication network may cause network congestion. On the other hand, if the fluctuations of the sampled states or measurement outputs are not worth acting on, releasing all the sampled data packets into the communication network is a waste of scarce network resources.

Therefore, how to efficiently choose sampled data packets to be released into the communication network motivates the study of the event-triggering mechanism [23], [24]. For the event-triggering mechanism in NCSs, some valuable results have also been reported [25]- [31]. Note that the event parameters in their event-triggering mechanisms are fixed and not adjustable. Different from the results in [25]- [31], adjustable event parameters have been constructed in [32] to introduce more flexibility for the event-triggering mechanism.

In fault detection for NCSs, on the one hand, if the occurrence of faults is detected, then, the system can respond by transmitting less data packets to save scarce network bandwidth resources. On the other hand, NCSs are subject to variable fault occurrence probability which can be obtained by using historical data. If the fault occurrence probability is low, the system can also choose to transmit less data packets. However, when investigating fault detection for event-triggered NCSs, the fault occurrence probability has received little attention except in [32]. Moreover, the event-triggering status is ignored in the literature. Specifically speaking, if the events are continuously triggered for θ times with θ > 0, a less sensitive event-triggering condition may be utilized to release less measurement outputs and/or control inputs, and save network bandwidth resources accordingly; if the events are continuously untriggered for θ times, a more sensitive event-triggering condition may be utilized to release more measurement outputs and/or control inputs, and improve the system performance accordingly. How to take into account the fault occurrence detection progress (which means that whether the occurrence of faults is detected) and the fault occurrence probability simultaneously, and introduce an adaptively adjusted eventtriggering parameter to achieve the efficient utilization of the communication network are, to our knowledge, yet unresolved. Answering these questions is the second and main motivation of the current work.

We observe that only the sensor is taken as event-triggered in [30]- [32]. In fault detection for NCSs, if both the sensor and the control station are event-triggered, less data packets will be released and network resources can be saved accordingly. When dealing with fault detection for event-triggered NCSs equipped with a control station, considering both the event-triggered sensor and the event-triggered control station can lead to a further reduced network bandwidth occupation. However, it will also introduce much difficulty for modeling and FDF design. How to tackle this issue is the third motivation of this paper.

This paper is concerned with adaptively adjusted eventtriggering mechanism-based fault detection for a discrete-time NCS subject to plant faults. A novel coordinated eventtriggering mechanism, which is based on the fault occurrence detection progress, the fault occurrence probability, and an adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter, is proposed. The simultaneously event-triggered sensor and control station are utilized to establish new closed-loop models, which are based on for the event-triggered simultaneous design of FDF and controller. We further furnish a new algorithm for choosing the adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter in order to achieve the efficient utilization of network resources.
The proposed event-triggering mechanism and fault detection scheme are applied to aircraft dynamics and shown to be effective.
The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) A coordinated event-triggering mechanism, which takes into account the fault occurrence detection progress and the fault occurrence probability, and incorporates an adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter, is proposed for the first time. A new adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter selection algorithm is proposed.
2) The event-triggered simultaneous design of FDF and controller is proposed to detect the occurrence of faults. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows.

Section II establishes new network-based models for the discrete-time NCS. Section III is concerned with the simultaneous design of FDF and controller. Performance analysis and design consideration are presented in Section IV. Some closing remarks are given in Section V.

div.head: A. Modeling NCS Subject to Dual-Channel Network-Induced Delays
div.p: In this section, we model an NCS subject to dual-channel network-induced delays. More specifically, the delays are the sensor-to-control station network-induced delays and the control station-to-actuator network-induced delays. Both the sensor and the control station are event-triggered. Under these conditions, the following FDF and controller can be adopted to generate the residual signal:

div.p: where x(k) ∈ R n and u(k) ∈ R m denote the state of the FDF and the output of the FDF, respectively; r(k) ∈ R q denotes the residual signal; y c (k) denotes the measurement output which is transmitted to the control station through a communication network channel; xc 1 (k) and xc 2 (k) denote artificially constructed vectors which will be discussed below in (7), while c 1 and c 2 imply that the influences of a communication network channel are taken into account to construct xc 1 (k) and xc 2 (k); and A f , B f , C f , D f , G f , and K are to be designed.
Note that D f xc 1 (k) and G f xc 2 (k) are introduced in (5) to avoid bilinear matrix inequalities which are encountered in the simultaneous design of FDF and controller.

As discussed in Section I, if the occurrence of faults has been detected and/or the fault occurrence probability is low, the system can release less data packets into the communication network. Moreover, introducing an adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter can lead to the efficient utilization of the communication network. Therefore, it is of paramount importance to propose the adaptively adjusted event-triggering mechanism which takes into account both the fault occurrence detection progress (which means that whether a fault occurrence is detected) and the fault occurrence probability.
The event generators 1 and 2 in Fig. 1 determine whether the newly sampled measurement outputs and control inputs should be released to the control station and the actuator, respectively.

Remark 2: The problems of fault detection for a discretetime NCS and fault detection for a continuous-time NCS are studied in this paper and our related work in [32], respectively. It should be mentioned that there are significant differences. A coordinated event-triggering mechanism, which takes into account the fault occurrence detection progress, the fault occurrence probability, and an adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter selection algorithm, is proposed in this paper, while the simultaneous network bandwidth utilization ratio and fault occurrence probability-based eventtriggering mechanism is proposed in [32]. The event-triggered sensor and control station are utilized simultaneously to further reduce the network bandwidth occupation in this paper, while only event-triggered sensors are taken into account in [32]. The sensor-to-control station and the control station-to-actuator network-induced delays are considered simultaneously in this paper. However, only the sensor-to-FDF network-induced characteristics are investigated in [32]. Thus, compared with [32], this paper provides some novel results.

div.head: B. Modeling NCS Subject to Single-Channel Network-Induced Delays
div.p: In this section, we consider the NCS in which only the sensor and the control station are connected through a communication network, while the control station is connected to the actuator directly. Here, network-induced delays in the sensor-to-control station communication network channel should be taken into full consideration, and the sensor is event-triggered to save the communication network bandwidth. If network-induced delays in the control station-to-actuator communication network channel are negligible and no eventtriggering mechanism is utilized at the control station, then, system (17) becomes

To clarify the process of the adaptively adjusted eventtriggering mechanism-based fault detection, we introduce the following iterative algorithm.
Algorithm 1:

Step 1: Choose appropriate event-triggering parameters α 1 , α 2 , and α 3 , and an appropriate initial instant k 0 . Set the value of η(0) as η(k 0 ). Calculate the values of r e (k 0 ), J(k 0 ), and y(k 0 ). Introduce an array "instants" to record the triggering instants of the condition in (6). Incorporate two buffers "memory-y" and "memory-eta" for holding the recently released measurement output and the latest available η(k) with the initial k = k 0 . Choose the maximum operation time k for the fault detection system.

Define N CTE and N CUTE as the number of continuously triggered events and the number of continuously untriggered events, respectively. Let N CTE = 1 and N CUTE = 0. Choose the upper bounds of N CTE and N CUTE as NCTE and NCUTE , respectively. Introduce the counters N T = 0 and N UT = 0. Choose appropriate ρ m , ρ ini , and ρ M for ρ k , where
div.formula: ρ m < ρ ini < ρ M . Set ρ k = ρ ini .
div.p: Release the first measurement output y(k 0 ) to the control station; update the values of the array instants, and the buffers memory-y and memory-eta.

Step 2: If the occurrence of faults has been detected, go to step 3. If the occurrence of faults is not detected, choose λ 1 (k) = 0; and if the fault occurrence probability is higher than a given threshold ε, choose λ 2 (k) = 1, otherwise, choose λ 2 (k) = 0. Calculate the value for α(k) in (6). Go to step 4.
Step 3: Choose λ 1 (k) = 1. Calculate the value for α(k) in (6).

Step 4: If the event-triggering condition ( 6) is satisfied, go to step 5. If the event-triggering condition ( 6) is not satisfied, set k = k + 1, based on the value of memory-eta, calculate η(k), r e (k), J(k), and y(k). If the fault occurrence is detected, generate a fault alarm. Set N CTE = 0 and N CUTE = N CUTE +1. Step 6: If k < k, go to step 2; otherwise, output the elements of the array instants, and stop.
Fig. 2 shows the flow diagram for Algorithm 1.

Remark 5: As observed from Algorithm 1, the adaptively adjusted event-triggering condition ( 6) is determined not by a simple inequality but by an algorithm. The event-triggering condition (6) takes into account both the fault occurrence detection progress and the fault occurrence probability, while the parameter ρ k is adjusted adaptively to achieve efficient utilization of the communication network bandwidth. By combining the event-triggering condition (6) and Algorithm 1, one can achieve good fault detection performance without causing network congestion. Therefore, the event-triggering condition ( 6) is more general than the existing ones.

Remark 6: From step 4 of Algorithm 1, one can see that if N CUTE = NCUTE and ρ k ≥ ρ M , N UT is set as N UT + 1. A large N UT implies that a larger ρ M should be chosen, which leads to the more easily satisfied event-triggering condition ( 6) and improved fault detection and control performance. Similarly, from step 5 of Algorithm 1, one can see that if N CTE = NCTE and ρ k ≤ ρ m , N T is set as N T + 1. A large N T implies that a smaller ρ m should be chosen, which leads to a more difficultly satisfied event-triggering condition ( 6) and a reduced communication network occupation. It is clear that there is a tradeoff between the system performance and the communication network occupation. Indeed, using Algorithm 1 can achieve such a tradeoff.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The adaptively adjusted event-triggering mechanism-based simultaneous design of FDF and controller for a discrete-time NCS subject to faults, and the sensor-to-control station and the control station-to-actuator network-induced delays has been studied. The event-triggered sensor and the event-triggered control station, the fault occurrence detection progress, the fault occurrence probability, and an adaptively adjusted eventtriggering parameter have been taken into account to establish new network-based closed-loop models. A new algorithm for choosing the adaptively adjusted event-triggering parameter has been given to achieve the efficient utilization of the communication network bandwidth. Based on the established models, the simultaneous design of FDF and controller has been presented. The effectiveness of the event-triggered simultaneous design of FDF and controller has been verified by the performance analysis of aircraft dynamics.
